citations.narrative:
There were multiple adult dogs and puppies delivered by the transporter that were picked up from USDA licensed
breeders that did not have the proper health certificates kept for record keeping. There were transports from November
27, 2023 of 3 puppies and 2 adult dogs and on January 2, 2024 of 3 puppies that did not have any health certificates for
records.
The lack of health certificates for record keeping does not provide for proper traceability of the dogs during transport and
are required for health tracking purposes.
The accepting carrier or intermediate handler shall keep and maintain a copy of the health certification completed as
required by § 2.78, tendered with each live dog, cat, or nonhuman primate.
To be corrected by: March 15, 2024

There is no contingency plan in place for the transportation of dogs by the transporter.
The lack of a contigency plan could result in a delay in reaction time in the event of an emergency that could directly affect
the safety and health of the regulated animals.
Dealers, exhibitors, intermediate handlers, and carriers must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to
provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an
emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and
well-being of the animals in their possession).
To be corrected by: March 24, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with registrant.
n

narrative:
2.77 
   
Records: Carriers and intermediate handlers. 
There were multiple adult dogs and puppies delivered by the transporter that were picked up from USDA licensed 
breeders that did not have the proper health certificates kept for record keeping. There were transports from November 
27, 2023 of 3 puppies and 2 adult dogs and on January 2, 2024 of 3 puppies that did not have any health certificates for 
records. 
 
The lack of health certificates for record keeping does not provide for proper traceability of the dogs during transport and 
are required for health tracking purposes. 
 
The accepting carrier or intermediate handler shall keep and maintain a copy of the health certification completed as 
required by § 2.78, tendered with each live dog, cat, or nonhuman primate. 
 
To be corrected by: March 15, 2024 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
There is no contingency plan in place for the transportation of dogs by the transporter. 
 
The lack of a contigency plan could result in a delay in reaction time in the event of an emergency that could directly affect 
the safety and health of the regulated animals.  
 
Dealers, exhibitors, intermediate handlers, and carriers must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to 
provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an 
emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and 
well-being of the animals in their possession).  
 
To be corrected by: March 24, 2024

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with registrant.
